docs.snippet: Four United States Navy surface ships and two submarines left American ports today to join forces with eight South American countries for war games in the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans and the Caribbean, the Navy said.   A Peruvian submarine will...
docs.lead_paragraph: Four United States Navy surface ships and two submarines left American ports today to join forces with eight South American countries for war games in the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans and the Caribbean, the Navy said. A Peruvian submarine will accompany the United States ships on a counterclockwise trip around the South American continent beginning Friday.

headline.main: SHIPS SAIL FOR LATIN WAR GAMES

docs.snippet: Two weeks after a bombing attack on Eden Pastora Gomez, an anti-Sandinista rebel leader, the Costa Rican authorities have established a key suspect - a man who, using a stolen Danish passport, traveled the region in recent months posing as a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Two weeks after a bombing attack on Eden Pastora Gomez, an anti-Sandinista rebel leader, the Costa Rican authorities have established a key suspect - a man who, using a stolen Danish passport, traveled the region in recent months posing as a photographer. That is nearly all they know. The man's identity remains a mystery. His current whereabouts is unknown. For whom he was working, if anyone, at the time of the blast has not been determined. It is not known whether he acted alone or with the help of others.

headline.main: ATTACK ON PASTORA: MUCH INTRIGUE BUT FEW FACTS

docs.snippet: Like Washington crossing the Delaware, Wilson Ferreira Aldunate, an exiled Uruguayan presidential candidate, plans to make his way across the choppy, chocolate Rio de la Plata to Montevideo to challenge the Government of Uruguay.   This crossing,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Like Washington crossing the Delaware, Wilson Ferreira Aldunate, an exiled Uruguayan presidential candidate, plans to make his way across the choppy, chocolate Rio de la Plata to Montevideo to challenge the Government of Uruguay. This crossing, however, is political. A group of 500 supporters and journalists will accompany Mr. Ferreira Aldunate aboard a lumbering ferry, amid great international fanfare. The venture seems likely to end with Mr. Ferreira Aldunate's arrest.

headline.main: A URUGUAYAN POLITICIAN IS TAKING ON THE GENERALS

docs.snippet: Wilson Ferreira Aldunate, an exiled Uruguayan presidential candidate, left Argentina Friday night and was arrested today aboard a ferry by the Uruguayan Navy as he was returning to his homeland for the first time in 11 years.   Warships intercepted...
docs.lead_paragraph: Wilson Ferreira Aldunate, an exiled Uruguayan presidential candidate, left Argentina Friday night and was arrested today aboard a ferry by the Uruguayan Navy as he was returning to his homeland for the first time in 11 years. Warships intercepted the ferry carrying Mr. Ferreira Aldunate and 400 political supporters and journalists in a midmorning fog after an all-night crossing of the Rio de la Plata. More than 50,000 chanting and singing Uruguayans covered a boulevard leading to the defunct National Congress here in an antimilitary protest to greet Mr. Ferreira Aldunate.

docs.snippet: One of the country's two dominant parties today broke off all political transition talks with the ruling military until the Government releases the party's presidential candidate and his son.   The action was taken at a convention of the National...
docs.lead_paragraph: One of the country's two dominant parties today broke off all political transition talks with the ruling military until the Government releases the party's presidential candidate and his son. The action was taken at a convention of the National Party, whose candidate, Wilson Ferreira Aldunate, was arrested along with his 31-year-old son, Juan Raul, on Saturday by the Government of Gen. Gregorio Alvarez as they entered Uruguayan waters aboard a chartered ferry crossing the Rio de la Plata from Buenos Aires. The two, who had been living in exile, were being held today at separate military camps in the interior, according to family members.

headline.main: JAILED POLITICIAN'S PARTY HALTS TALKS WITH URUGUAY MILITARY

docs.snippet: Voting for the European Parliament dealt defeats for both the left and right, with the French left apparently the biggest loser, according to computer projections and partial results. (Page A1, Column 6.)  Poles seemed unenthusiastic as they voted...
docs.lead_paragraph: Voting for the European Parliament dealt defeats for both the left and right, with the French left apparently the biggest loser, according to computer projections and partial results. (Page A1, Column 6.) Poles seemed unenthusiastic as they voted for local councils throughout the country in the first election since martial law was imposed in December 1981. The atmosphere was calm, and the clandestine calls in Warsaw for demonstrations were overhwelmingly ignored. (A1:4.)

docs.snippet: Latin America's leading debtor nations began meeting in Cartagena, Colombia, today to design a strategy to deal with their creditors without raising the specter of a regional moratorium on debt payments.    Spokesmen for several governments have...
docs.lead_paragraph: Latin America's leading debtor nations began meeting in Cartagena, Colombia, today to design a strategy to deal with their creditors without raising the specter of a regional moratorium on debt payments. Spokesmen for several governments have stressed that the purpose is not to form a debtors' cartel but rather to develop principles to guide countries in renegotiating debts and seeking new credits. Brazil's Foreign Minister, Ramiro Saraiva Guerreiro, said on Friday that the conference ''does not have the aim of confrontation but rather of awakening reflection over the common interests of debtors and creditors.'' Mexico's Foreign Minister, Bernardo Sepulveda Amor, said its purpose was to find ''new formulas'' and establish ''new rules of the game.''

docs.snippet: The Government says a military judge has formally charged the presidential candidate Wilson Ferreira Aldunate with aiding subversion and three other counts.   If convicted by a military court, Mr. Ferreira Aldunate could be sentenced to 20 years in...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Government says a military judge has formally charged the presidential candidate Wilson Ferreira Aldunate with aiding subversion and three other counts. If convicted by a military court, Mr. Ferreira Aldunate could be sentenced to 20 years in prison, lawyers said.

headline.main: Uruguay Lists Charges Against Opposition Chief

docs.snippet: A consensus began to emerge among 11 Latin American countries today they they might form a commission to represent them in proposed talks with industrial nations on setting a new framework to refinance third-world debt.    Agreement on such a...
docs.lead_paragraph: A consensus began to emerge among 11 Latin American countries today they they might form a commission to represent them in proposed talks with industrial nations on setting a new framework to refinance third-world debt. Agreement on such a commission remained uncertain as its possible scope was still being discussed by the foreign ministers and finance ministers assembled in this Spanish colonial coastal fortress. The talks opened today and will end Friday. Mexico's Finance Minister, Jesus Silva Herzog, appeared to represent the consensus when he said in an interview that the idea of a commission ''generalizes that the problem is not just a technical one of debtors and creditors but of governments and other political actors.''

headline.main: LATIN DEBTORS CONSIDER A PANEL TO SPEAK FOR ALL

docs.snippet: Eleven Latin American nations, including some of the most heavily indebted countries in the world, took their first concrete step today toward unity in dealing with the world debt crisis.    The nations meeting here agreed in a statement they called...
docs.lead_paragraph: Eleven Latin American nations, including some of the most heavily indebted countries in the world, took their first concrete step today toward unity in dealing with the world debt crisis. The nations meeting here agreed in a statement they called the Consensus of Cartagena to set up a rotating secretariat among themselves and come together in frequent meetings. The agreement called for the meetings in order to ''reflect together'' on the debt crisis. In the agreement, the Latin Americans called for the establishment of a working group of industrial and third world nations inside the World Bank's development committee to consider a wide- ranging list of proposals.

headline.main: 11 LATIN NATIONS PLAN TO CONSULT REGULARLY ON REGION'S DEBT CRISIS
